z:row.TitlePrimary: 4-Node Flat Shell Element - Drilling Degrees of Freedom, Membrane Bending Coupling, Warped Geometry, and Behavior
z:row.Keyword: TRIANGULAR ELEMENT|FORMULATION|PLATE|Computer Science, Interdisciplinary Applications|Engineering, Civil
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers & Structures
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: COOK, RD, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH & ASTRONAUT,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A very simple way to obtain a quadrilateral shell element is to write membrane and bending stiffness matrices for a flat geometry and add them. This basic membrane-plus-bending element can be modified to incorporate membrane-bending coupling and to accommodate a geometry in which the four nodes are not coplanar. The present paper develops a 24 degree of freedom quadrilateral shell element and concurrently provides a status report on the formulation method by pointing out what works and what does not. Numerical results are good: the element is not the best available four-node shell element in all test cases but is far from the worst.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Further Development of a 3-Node Triangular Shell Element
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: COOK, RD, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A three-node triangular shell element having six d.o.f. per node can be economically generated as a flat element that combines well-known formulations for membrane stiffness and plate bending stiffness. Early elements of this type were inaccurate because the membrane response was poor. Researchers improved the membrane response by adding drilling d.o.f. and by underintegrating the membrane stiffness matrix. More recent research has dealt with the addition of membrane-bending coupling within individual elements and the suppression of mechanisms. The present work intends to continue the improvement by modifying the membrane stiffness, simplifying the membrane-bending coupling device and suppressing mechanisms without degrading performance or causing the mesh to lock.

z:row.TitlePrimary: An Element Error Indicator and a Related Stress-Improvement Procedure
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Communications in Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: COOK, RD, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A posteriori error indicators for strain energy error in finite-element solutions have recently been shown to be effective. A popular error indicator, usually denoted by eta, makes use of 'error energy', i.e. strain energy associated with the difference between the conventional element stresses sigma and a smoothed stress field constructed from sigma. It is intended that eta be constructed by summing element contributions and that it be applied at the global level. The present study suggests that an error indicator applicable at the element level can be obtained by combining an element value of eta with information about stress gradient and strain energy density. It is also shown how the stress gradient information can be used to obtain more accurate stresses at mesh boundaries.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Error Estimation and Adaptive Meshing for Vibration Problems
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers & Structures
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: TECHNION ISRAEL INST TECHNOL,FAC MECH ENGN,IL-32000 HAIFA,ISRAEL.; COOK, RD, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: The paper discusses selected procedures for estimating the discretization error of finite element modeling as applied to the calculation of undamped natural frequencies of vibration. One method uses improved strain energy by smoothing the element-by-element stress field. Another method uses improved kinetic energy by using alternative mass matrices. Neither method requires the introduction of additional DOF. Error estimates are also used to identify elements whose discretization error is greatest, and thus drive mesh refinement by r- and h-methods. Axial vibrations of bars and in-plane vibrations of membranes are used as example problems.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Pure Bending of Curved Beams of Thin-Walled Rectangular Box Section
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Applied Mechanics-Transactions of the Asme
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A closed-form solution of the subject problem is presented. The analytical method resembles that used by Bleich (1933) to study curved beams of I or T section. It is found that the circumferential stress may be smaller than a perpendicular stress that arises from flexing of parts of the box. Accuracy of the solution is verified by comparison with finite element analyses.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam Cantilevered from Elastic Support - Finite-Element Modeling
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Communications in Applied Numerical Methods
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: COOK, RD, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A beam, modelled by standard beam elements, is to be connected to a plane, which is modelled by quadrilateral elements. Beam elements include rotational d.o.f. but quadrilateral elements do not. The connection is made by extending the beam into the plane by an additional beam element. Herein we present a formula for the stiffness of the additional beam element so that the elasticity of the support is properly represented.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Modified Formulations for 9-Dof Plane Triangles that Include Vertex Rotations
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: COOK, RD, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: This paper considers various procedures that yield improved stiffness matrices for plane triangular elements. Each element has nine d.o.f. and vertex nodes only. Some of the resulting elements are non-classical constant strain triangles while others have more competent displacement fields. Numerical examples suggest that the nine-d.o.f. element can either be formulated more efficiently or made more accurate, but probably not both at the same time.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Solid Elements with Rotational Degrees of Freedom .1. Hexahedron Elements
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.; YUNUS, SM, SWANSON ANAL SYST INC,POB 65,JOHNSON RD,HOUSTON,PA 15342.
z:row.Abstract: This is the first of a two part paper on three-dimensional finite elements with rotational degrees of freedom (DOF). Part I introduces an 8-node solid hexahedron element having three translational and three rotational DOF per node. The corner rotations are introduced by transformation of the midside translational DOF of a 20-node hexahedron element. The new element produces a much smaller effective band width of the global system equations than does the 20-node hexahedron element having midside nodes. A small penalty stiffness is introduced to augment the usual element stiffness so that no spurious zero energy modes are present. The new element passes the patch test and demonstrates greatly improved performance over elements of identical shape but having only translational DOF at the corner nodes.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Solid Elements with Rotational Degrees of Freedom .2. Tetrahedron Elements
z:row.Keyword: AUTOMATIC MESH GENERATION|FINITE-ELEMENTS|Engineering, Multidisciplinary|Mathematics, Interdisciplinary Applications
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX, ENGLAND PO19 1UD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.; PAWLAK, TP, SWANSON ANAL SYST INC,POB 65,JOHNSON RD,HOUSTON,PA 15342.
z:row.Abstract: This is the second part of a two part paper on three-dimensional finite elements with rotational degrees of freedom (DOF). Part II introduces a solid tetrahedron element having 3 translational and 3 rotational DOF per node. The corner rotations are introduced by transformation of the midside translational DOF of a 10-node tetrahedron element. To further enhance the element performance a least squares strain extraction technique is also implemented to develop the stiffness matrix with a desired field. The strain smoothing improves performance without causing a loss in generality. As with the hexahedron in Part I, the element stiffness is augmented with a small penalty stiffness to eliminate any possible spurious zero energy modes. The new tetrahedron element passes the patch test and demonstrates much improved performance over the 4-node translational DOF only (constant strain) tetrahedron element.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Four-node `flat' shell element: Drilling degrees of freedom, membrane-bending coupling, warped geometry, and behavior
z:row.Keyword: Shells (structures)|Structural analysis|Degrees of freedom (mechanics)|Bending (deformation)|Numerical analysis|Mathematical models
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Pergamon Press Inc, Tarrytown, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A very simple way to obtain a quadrilateral shell element is to write membrane and bending stiffness matrices for a flat geometry and add them. This basic membrane-plus-bending element can be modified to incorporate membrane-bending coupling and to accommodate a geometry in which the four nodes are not coplanar. The present paper develops a 24 degree of freedom quadrilateral shell element and concurrently provides a status report on the formulation method by pointing out what works and what does not. Numerical results are good: the element is not the best available four-node shell element in all test cases but is far from the worst.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Four node flat shell element; Membrane plus bending element; Membrane-bending coupling

z:row.TitlePrimary: Finite element analysis of a femur with a cementless hip prosthesis under muscle forces during stair climbing
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1994 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, Nov 6-11 1994
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Bioengineering Division (Publication) BED
z:row.Keyword: Bone|Hip prostheses|Biomechanics|Muscle|Finite element method|Mathematical models|Loads (forces)|Stress analysis|Shear stress|Geometry
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to locate the interface shear and normal stress distributions in the cortical bone under realistic muscle forces in stair climbing. Results showed that the highest values of normal stress in cortical bone at bone-implant interface were found in the medial side and the highest values of shear stress were found to be on the X-Y surface.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Stair climbing; Muscle force; Trabecular bone; Greater trochanter

z:row.TitlePrimary: Stem stiffness optimization and material properties evaluation of the hip prosthesis
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1994 International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, Nov 6-11 1994
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Bioengineering Division (Publication) BED
z:row.Keyword: Hip prostheses|Implants (surgical)|Shear stress|Bone|Optimization|Muscle|Joints (anatomy)|Titanium alloys|Carbon fiber reinforced plastics|Finite element method|Mathematical models|Biomechanics|Stiffness
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The aim of this paper is to use the shape optimization technique in order to obtain uniform normal stress distribution in the cortical bone. A reduction of the extreme shear stress values at the implant tip is also studied. This is achieved by optimizing the stem implant profile. The optimization technique is utilized to evaluate three commonly used implant material properties. Muscle forces and joint reactions generated during the stair climbing activity are applied to the structure.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Stress distribution; Stress shielding; Stair climbing

z:row.TitlePrimary: Further development of a three-node triangular shell element
z:row.Keyword: Shells (structures)|Degrees of freedom (mechanics)|Bending (deformation)|Dynamic response|Mathematical models|Finite element method
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A three-node triangular shell element having six d.o.f. per node can be economically generated as a flat element that combines well-known formulations for membrane stiffness and plate bending stiffness. Early elements of this type were inaccurate because the membrane response was poor. Researchers improved the membrane response by adding drilling d.o.f. and by underintegrating the membrane stiffness matrix. More recent research has dealt with the addition of membrane-bending coupling within individual elements and the suppression of mechanisms. The present work intends to continue the improvement by modifying the membrane stiffness, simplifying the membrane-bending coupling device and suppressing mechanisms without degrading performance or causing the mesh to lock.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Three node triangular shell element; Plate bending stiffness; Membrane stiffness; Membrane bending coupling; Drilling degrees of freedom; Suppressing mechanisms; Membrane response; Underintegration; Stiffness matrix

z:row.TitlePrimary: Element error indicator and a related stress-improvement procedure
z:row.Keyword: STrain|Finite element method|Error analysis|Stress analysis|Fracture mechanics
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Communications in Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A posteriori error indicators for strain energy error in finite-element solutions have recently been shown to be effective. A popular error indicator, usually denoted by η, makes use of 'error energy', i.e. strain energy associated with the difference between the conventional element stresses σ and a smoothed stress field constructed from σ. It is intended that η be constructed by summing element contributions and that it be applied at the global level. The present study suggests that an error indicator applicable at the element level can be obtained by combining an element value-of η with information about stress gradient and strain energy density. It is also shown how the stress gradient information can be used to obtain more accurate stresses at mesh boundaries.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Element error indicators; Strain energy; Stress gradients

z:row.TitlePrimary: Circumferential stresses in curved beams
z:row.Keyword: Rotors -- Structural Analysis|Structural Analysis - Dynamic Response|Beams and Girders - Stresses|Beams and Girders - Bending
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Applied Mechanics, Transactions ASME
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the author's previous paper on the related topic, the parametric instability of the viscoelastic rotor-disk system under dynamic axial loads was analyzed. In the present paper, the global stability of a simply-supported multidisk rotor system under the combined effects of tangential torque, axial forces, and internal structural damping is considered. In this analysis the author assumes that both the tangential torque and axial forces are fully dynamic in nature with a periodic sinusoidal component superimposed on a constant value.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Curved Beam Circumferential Stresses; Beam Direct Stress; Beam Bending Stress

z:row.TitlePrimary: Error estimation and adaptive meshing for vibration problems
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The paper discusses selected procedures for estimating the discretization error of finite element modeling as applied to the calculation of undamped natural frequencies of vibration. One method uses improved strain energy by smoothing the element-by-element stress field. Another method uses improved kinetic energy by using alternative mass matrices. Neither method requires the introduction of additional DOF. Error estimates are also used to identify elements whose discretization error is greatest, and thus drive mesh refinement by r- and h-methods. Axial vibrations of bars and in-plane vibrations of membranes are used as example problems.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Error estimation; Adaptive meshing; Discretization errors; Axial vibrations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Buckling analysis: Alternative formulations, error estimation, and adaptive meshing
z:row.Keyword: Mathematical Techniques -- Finite Element Method|Structural Analysis - Stresses|Mathematical Techniques - Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions|Mathematical Techniques - Error Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Finite Elements in Analysis and Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Finite element buckling analysis produces a generalized eigenproblem in which the eigenvalue λ multiplies what may be called a stress stiffness matrix. This paper presents new forms of this matrix, some of which seem always to produce an underestimate of λ. We combine such results with results from conventional formulations, which usually overestimate λ, to obtain reliable estimates for the error in computed buckling load. Calculations are straightforward and are easily arranged to give element-by-element error indicators that serve to drive adaptive meshing.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Stress Stiffness Matrix; Adaptive Meshing; Element by Element Error Indicators; Buckling Load

z:row.TitlePrimary: Error estimators for eigenvalues computed from discretized models of vibrating structures
z:row.Keyword: Structural Analysis -- Vibrations|Mathematical Techniques - Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions|Mathematical Techniques - Error Analysis|Vibrations - Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: AIAA Journal
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Numerical analysis of a solid, plate, or shell structure requires discretization, e.g., by finite elements. Realizing that discretization is accompanied by modeling error, the analysts seeks a level of mesh refinement that is adequate but not excessive. An error estimator for time-independent stress analysis, based on the discrepancy between smoothed and unsmoothed stress fields, has been suggested. This paper suggests two analogous estimators for error in computed natural frequencies. Both are postprocessing schemes that use the Rayleigh quotient.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Vibrating Structure Discretized Models; Structure Eigenvalues; Undamped Free Vibrations; Eigenvalue Error Estimates; Rayleigh Quotient

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam cantilevered from elastic support. Finite-element modelling
z:row.Keyword: Beams and Girders -- Elasticity|Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method|Mathematical Models
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Communications in Applied Numerical Methods
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A beam, modelled by standard beam elements, is to be connected to a plane, which is modelled by quadrilateral elements. Beam elements include rotational d.o.f. but quadrilateral elements do not. The connection is made by extending the beam into the plane by an additional beam element. Herein we present a formula for the stiffness of the additional beam element so that the elasticity of the support is properly represented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Cantilever Beams; Quadrilateral Elements; Stiffness; Elastic Supports

z:row.TitlePrimary: Pure bending of curved beams of thin-walled rectangular box section
z:row.Keyword: Beams and Girders -- Bending|Mathematical Techniques - Finite Element Method|Stresses - Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Applied Mechanics, Transactions ASME
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A closed-form solution of the subject problem is presented. The analytical method resembles that used by Bleich (1933) to study curved beams of I or T section. It is found that the circumferential stress may be smaller than a perpendicular stress that arises from flexing of parts of the box. Accuracy of the solution is verified by comparison with finite element analyses.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Curved Beam Pure Bending Analysis; Thin-Walled Rectangular Box Section; Straight Beam Theory; Circumferential Stress Analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: Modified formulations for nine-d.o.f. plane triangles that include vertex rotations
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper considers various procedures that yield improved stiffness matrices for plane triangular elements. Each element has nine d.o.f. and vertex nodes only. Some of the resulting elements are non-classical constant strain triangles while others have more competent displacement fields. Numerical examples suggest that the nine-d.o.f. element can either be formulated more efficiently or made more accurate, but probably not both at the same time.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Stiffness Matrices; Triangular Elements

z:row.TitlePrimary: Vibration of a segment of a non-circular cylindrical shell. The 'musical saw' problem
z:row.Keyword: Domes and Shells -- Vibrations|Vibrations - Analysis|Mathematical Models|Computers - Applications
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Sound and Vibration
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Consider a thin flat plate in the shape of an elongated quadrilateral, e.g., the blade of a standard cross-cut saw. By imposing tip displacement wL and tip rotation θL, various shapes and amplitudes of deflection are possible. Thus deflected, the plate becomes a segment of a non-circular cylindrical shell with long edges free, and the y axis becomes a generator of the cylinder. Such an arrangement constitutes the 'musical saw', which is played as a folk instrument: one hand strokes a bow across a long edge; the other hand imposes wL and θL to change the pitch. The tone produced is reminiscent of the tone of a theremin. What vibration mode accounts for the distinctive tone? And what mechanism accounts for changes in pitch? In the present note these questions are addressed by a combination of experiment and finite element analysis.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Non-Circular Cylindrical Shell; Musical Saw Problem; Images-3D Program; Four-Node Shell Elements; Theory of Cylindrical Shells; Elastic Foundation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Finite element analysis of closely-coiled helical springs
z:row.Keyword: Springs -- Helical|Stresses - Analysis|Mathematical Techniques - Finite Element Method
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: I consider the deflection and state of stress in a closely-coiled helical spring. The cross-section of a coil may have arbitrary shape. A simple finite element procedure is described, in which there is a single displacement degree of freedom for each node and also a 'global' freedom, for a total of N + 1 d.o.f. in a finite element model of N nodes.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Simulating curved elements by offsets. Rationale and application to shells of revolution
z:row.Keyword: Domes and Shells -- Computer Simulation|Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method|Computer Programming--Algorithms|Arches--Computer Simulation|Mechanisms--Analogies
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Engineering Computations (Swansea, Wales)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In a previous note, curved arch elements were simulated by attaching rigid offsets to nodes of straight elements. The procedure was physically motivated. Here the offsets method is derived by shell theory and is seen to lie in the context of standard assumed-displacement field finite-element theory. Application to shells of revolution is provided.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Curved Elements Simulation; Shells of Revolution; Two Point Gauss Quadrature; Marguerre Shallow Shell Theory; Rigid Offsets

z:row.TitlePrimary: Some options for plane triangular elements with rotational degrees of freedom
z:row.Keyword: Mathematical Techniques -- Finite Element Method|Structural Analysis|Beams and Girders--Deflection
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Finite Elements in Analysis and Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: We consider a nine-d.o.f. plane triangular element having vertex nodes and rotational d.o.f., whose stiffness matrix is integrated by one-point Gauss quadrature. This paper discusses ways to improve performance, by division into subelements and by adding stabilization matrices to control mechanisms. Fortunately, it is found that the most effective scheme is also one of the simplest and most economical.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plane Triangular Elements; Rotational Degrees of Freedom; Subelements

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radial stress formula for curved beams
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vibration, Acoustics, Stress, and Reliability in Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper consider, a beam having initial curvature and loaded by forces that act in its plane. The material is linearly elastic, homogeneous, and isotropic. Cross sections are constant, and either have a radial axis of symmetry that contains the loads or are constrained not to rotate in their planes. Thus, the neutral axis of each cross section is parallel to the axis of revolution of the curved beam. The formula for circumferential stress σθ is well known. Formulas for shear stress τrθ and radial stress σr were presented by T.S. Wang and C.H. Tsao. In the paper an improved formula for radial stress is presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Radial Stress Formula; Curved Beams

z:row.TitlePrimary: Axisymmetric finite element analysis for pure moment loading of curved beams and pipe bends
z:row.Keyword: Beams and Girders -- Curved|Pipe Fittings--Stresses|Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A curved body is considered, such as a portion of a toroid between two radial planes. The body may be massive or thin-walled, and is loaded on end faces by moments whose vectors are parallel to the axis of revolution. A simple analysis method is described, in which standard finite element interpolations are augmented by a global degree of freedom that is shared by all elements. Thus the problem is mathematically two-dimensional. Numerical results appear to be reasonably accurate.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Pure Moment Loading; Pipe Bends

z:row.TitlePrimary: Improvement in peak stress estimates through post-processing
z:row.Keyword: Stresses -- Computation|Computer Systems, Digital|Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method|Fracture Mechanics
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Finite Elements in Analysis and Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Three alternatives for calculating the peak stress in the vicinity of a stress raiser have been proposed in previous research: an iterative method, a stiffness derivative method, and a table look-up method. The goal of each is to improve the estimate of the peak stress through post-processing rather than multiple analyses utilizing mesh refinement. In the present paper, the relative effectiveness of the methods is studied by means of test cases. An improved stiffness derivative method is suggested for use in fracture mechanics applications.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Peak Stress; Post-Processing

z:row.TitlePrimary: APPLICATION OF THE FINITE ELEMENT-DIFFERENCE METHOD TO VIBRATION PROBLEMS
z:row.Keyword: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES -- Finite Element Method|VIBRATIONS - Analysis|STRESSES - Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The so-called finite element-difference method introduced by R. D. Cook and X. Huang yields a continuous stress field by finite difference operations and finite element interpolations. In the present paper, applications of the method to vibration problems are discussed. The inverse iteration procedure is modified for this method. Numerical results show that the accuracy of solutions depends strongly on the type of finite difference operator chosen: for reliable and accurate solutions in modal analysis problems, element internal strains must be included in the strain field used to compute nodal forces associated with element deformations.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: MODAL ANALYSIS

z:row.TitlePrimary: PLANE HYBRID ELEMENT WITH ROTATIONAL D. O. F. AND ADJUSTABLE STIFFNESS
z:row.Keyword: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES -- Finite Element Method|STRESSES - Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A simple formulation of a nine d. o. f. plane triangle is achieved by the assumed-stress hybrid approach. The element has two translations and the rotation about a normal to the plane as d. o. f. at each node. Performance of the element is shown to be good. A device for softening overly-stiff elements is found to be effective and is suggested as a widely applicable method of improving the behaviour of hybrid elements. A particularly simple form of the element, herein called the CST Hybrid, appears to be the best performer.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: PLANE HYBRID ELEMENT; STIFFNESS

z:row.TitlePrimary: STRESSES IN A TENSILE STRIP WITH A LARGE CIRCULAR HOLE
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper considers the determination of the stress concentration factor at the edge of a large circular hole in a flat strip under tension, as the diameter of the hole approaches the width of the strip. It is found that the stress concentration factor decreases as load increases, going from 1. 94 to a limiting value of 1. 00.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TENSILE STRIP; STRESS CONCENTRATION FACTOR

z:row.TitlePrimary: CONTINUOUS STRESS FIELDS BY THE FINITE ELEMENT-DIFFERENCE METHOD
z:row.Keyword: STRESSES -- Analysis|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method|STRAIN
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Standard finite elements yield a stress field that is discontinuous across interelement boundaries. In this paper, results given by standard finite elements are postprocessed by an efficient iterative scheme that makes use of modal strains, finite difference operations and interpolations that augment (and may differ from) the shape functions used to generate the element stiffness matrix. Various types of interpolation are considered. Each leads to a continuous stress field that is more accurate than the unprocessed stress field.

z:row.User2: STIFFNESS MATRICES

z:row.TitlePrimary: ON THE ALLMAN TRIANGLE AND A RELATED QUADRILATERAL ELEMENT
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: D. J. Allman has introduced a plane triangular element whose nodal d. o. f. are two displacements and one rotation at each corner. In this note, the Allman element is regarded as the results of applying a coordinate transformation to an element that has midside nodes. Thus, the technique is easily applied to elements other than triangles. Results for the analogous quadrilateral are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: ALLMAN TRIANGLE; QUADRILATERAL ELEMENT

z:row.TitlePrimary: LARGE-DEFLECTION ANALYSIS OF CYLINDRICAL WATER TANKS WITH AXES HORIZONTAL
z:row.Keyword: WATER TANKS AND TOWERS -- Analysis|CYLINDERS - Deflection|STRESSES - Analysis|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Algorithms
z:row.Publisher: Swanson Analysis Systems Inc, Houston, PA, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Pittsburgh, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A cylindrical tank, partially or completely full, has its axis horizontal. Supports on either side run lengthwise. If the tank wall is very thin, standard formulas greatly overestimate the stresses because these formulas neglect the effects of deformation. In this paper a nonlinear analysis is described and sample results are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: NONLINEAR ANALYSIS; STRESS-SMOOTHING SCHEMES; NODAL LOADS; NUMERICAL TESTS; MAXIMUM FLEXURAL STRESS

z:row.TitlePrimary: BEHAVIOR OF CYLINDRICAL TANKS WHOSE AXES ARE HORIZONTAL
z:row.Keyword: TANKS -- Cylinders|STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS - Stresses|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Nonlinear Equations
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Thin-Walled Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A cylindrical tank is mounted with its axis horizontal. Supports on either side run lengthwise. If the tank wall is thin, deformations significantly affect the stresses, so that standard stress formulae (which ignore deformations) may over-estimate stresses by a factor of ten or more. In this paper, deformations are accounted for by a nonlinear analysis. Stresses and deformed shapes are reported for various positions of the supports, radius to thickness ratios, and depths of fill.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: HORIZONTAL AXIS; SUPPORTS

z:row.TitlePrimary: PARTITIONED FINITE ELEMENT METHOD FOR DYNAMICAL SYSTEMS
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new analytical method is described for deriving the equations of motion of dynamical systems. The concept considers the displacements of the domain to be composed of rigid and elastic components. The domain modeled by finite number of degrees of freedom is discretized into two distinctive types of subdomains. Rigid and elastic subdomains are generated by consistent lumping of the domain properties under unique kinematic constraint relations. Equations of motion of the disjoint subdomains are derived by Lagrange's equations, in conjunction with the shape function matrix represented in partitioned form. This allows reduced sizes of matrices and avoids their possible singularities. Based on the invariance of energies under a compatible partitioned procedure, a simple analytical method is introduced for building the equations of motion of the whole domain from those of the subdomain.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: ITERATIVE PROCEDURE FOR FINITE-ELEMENT STRESS ANALYSIS OF FRICTIONAL CONTACT PROBLEMS
z:row.Keyword: WOODEN CONSTRUCTION|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method|STRESSES - Computer Aided Analysis|FRICTION
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: A simple, efficient, versatile and easily adaptable, iterative finite-element technique is described. The method is based on logical steps to establish the contact geometry and regions of slip and nonslip. Unlike previous techniques, the approach can be extended readily to multiple contact surfaces. The scheme is demonstrated by analyzing a mechanical joint in orthotropic wood. In this case, mixed coordinate systems are used to enhance accuracy of the stresses near the pin contact region. The numerically computed values agree with those reported elsewhere.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: DEFLECTION AND BUCKLING OF RINGS WITH STRAIGHT AND CURVED FINITE ELEMENTS
z:row.Keyword: RINGS - STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - FINITE ELEMENT METHOD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIVI OF WIS, MADISON, USA
z:row.Abstract: A PLANE CIRCULAR RING IS MODELED BY VARIOUS ELEMENTS, SOME STRAIGHT AND OTHERS CURVED. ALL FORMULATIONS HAVE TWO TRANSLATIONS AND ONE ROTATION AS NODAL DEGREE OF FREEDOM. THE PAPER CONSIDERS STATIC DEFLECTION, UNDER POINT LOADING, AND BIFURCATION BUCKLING, UNDER CONSTANT-DIRECTION LOADING AND FLUIDPRESSURE LOADING. MATRICES THAT ACCOUNT FOR FLUID PRESSURE LOADING ARE DERIVED. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES SHOW THAT EXCELLENT RESULTS ARE GIVEN BY A STANDARD STRAIGHT BEAM ELEMENT WHOSE LENGTH IS THAT OF THE ARC IT SUBTENDS.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: LOUBIGNAC'S ITERATIVE METHOD IN FINITE ELEMENT ELASTOSTATICS
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: Finte element models provide only approximate results under most loadings. A beam modelled by constant-strain triangles and loaded by pure moment is a case in point. Yet if the iterative method advanced by G. Loubignac et al. is applied to this model, the exact stress field will be generated. The iterative method derives from a parent formulation that can be solved without iteration. As shown in this paper, the parent formulation contains the sum of two stiffness matrices. Loubignac's method produces a stress field that is continuous across interelement boundaries. Other methods that seek to impose interelement continuity are noted in the concluding section.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: CONTROL OF SPURIOUS MODES IN THE NINE-NODE QUADRILATERAL ELEMENT
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV OF WIS, MADISON, USA
z:row.Abstract: THE NINE-NODE QUADRILATERAL IS MUCH MORE ACCURATE THAN ITS EIGHT-NODE RELATIVE IF ELEMENTS ARE NON-RECTANGULAR. HOWEVER, THE NINE-NODE ELEMENT MAY DISPLAY SPURIOUS LOW-ENERGY MODES UNDER 2 * 2 GAUSS QUADRATURE. THESE MODES CAN BE CONTROLLED BY USING THE 3 * 3 QUADRATURE RULE, BUT AT ADDED COST. THIS PAPER INVESTIGATES TWO INEXPENSIVE CONTROL DEVICES THAT CAN BE USED WITH 2 * 2 GAUSS QUADRATURE.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS

z:row.TitlePrimary: DISTRIBUTED PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES: DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION
z:row.Keyword: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES|COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL - Distributed|COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Algorithms
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computer Communications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Computer Sciences Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The important issues in programming language design are examined for distributed computing and an example of a language philosophy is described which supports program development for a distributed environment. It also discusses experiences with the STARMOD distributed programming language.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: DISTRIBUTED PROGAMMING LANGUAGES

z:row.TitlePrimary: FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSIS OF THREADED CONNECTIONS
z:row.Keyword: BOLTS AND NUTS|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method
z:row.PeriodicalFull: American Society of Mechanical Engineers (Paper)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: This paper disusses the transfer of load in a threaded connection by finite elements without modeling the actual thread profile. The threads are modeled by a layer of elements with special properties. Parameters in a bolt-nut connection are varied to study their effect on the thread load distribution. Some unconventional nut forms, intended to improve the thread load distribution, are also investigated.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: A new eight-node solid element
z:row.Keyword: bending|classical mechanics of continuous media|finite element analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors present a new three-dimensional finite element, with the customary three displacement d.o.f. at each corner but no internal d.o.f. It passes the patch test and, for rectangular elements, exactly models pure bending. In numerical tests, the new element is found to be both accurate and efficient. It has the added advantage that its bending and twisting stiffnesses can be individually adjusted
z:row.User2: patch test; pure bending; twisting stiffnesses; eight node solid element; bending stiffness; three dimensional finite element

z:row.TitlePrimary: MODELLING THE LOAD TRANSFER IN THREADED CONNECTIONS BY THE FINITE ELEMENT METHOD
z:row.Keyword: BOLTS AND NUTS|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: A finite element model for stress analysis of threaded connections is introduced. Instead of modelling individual threads, the thread zone is replaced by a layer of elements with orthotropic properties. The principal directions of orthotropy depend upon the thread geometry and upon the direction of load, which is not necessarily known a priori. Both conventional and tapered threads are considered. The latter problem is nonlinear, as the number of threads in contact is a function of the load. Numerical results for conventional and tapered threads agree well with theoretical and experimental results in the literature.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: THREADED CONNECTIONS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Modelling the load transfer in threaded connections by the finite element method
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors introduce a finite element model for stress analysis of threaded connections. Instead of modelling individual threads, the thread zone is replaced by a layer of elements with orthotropic properties. The principal directions of orthotropy depend upon the thread geometry and upon the direction of load, which is not necessarily known a priori. Both conventional and tapered threads are considered. The latter problem is nonlinear, as the number of threads in contact is a function of the load. Numerical results for conventional and tapered threads agree well with theoretical and experimental results in the literature

z:row.TitlePrimary: A cost comparison of two static condensation-stress recovery algorithms
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors consider finite elements that have internal degrees-of-freedom. These d.o.f. are condensed before elements are assembled into the structure, and must be recovered later for use in element stress computation. The computation costs of two methods of performing these calculations are compared
z:row.User2: finite elements; static condensation stress recovery algorithms

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ways to improve the bending response of finite elements
z:row.Keyword: bending strength|finite element analysis|mechanical engineering computing
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Four new ways to excessive bending stiffness of linear elements are described and incorporated into plane elements. All satisfy the `patch test'. The new elements are compared with existing elements in test problems. Application to three-dimensional problems is proposed
z:row.User2: finite elements; bending stiffness; linear elements; plane elements; patch test; three dimensional problems

z:row.TitlePrimary: More about `artificial' softening of finite elements
z:row.Keyword: finite element analysis|mechanical engineering computing|stress analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method is proposed for making overly stiff elements more flexible. The central idea is quite simple and is illustrated by application to a sample element, whose behaviour is greatly improved. The effort needed to soften an element is very small if its stiffness matrix is naturally produced with reference to generalized co-ordinates before a final transformation to nodal displacement degrees-of-freedom
z:row.User2: stiffness matrix softening; finite element analysis; mechanical engineering computing; stress analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: Application of optimization and finite element methods to a cracking problem in timber
z:row.Keyword: crack-edge stress field analysis|finite element analysis|optimisation
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA

z:row.TitlePrimary: Further improvement of an effective plate bending element
z:row.Keyword: engineering applications of computers|finite element analysis|mechanical engineering
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Computers and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A previously derived finite element is improved by softening its slightly over-stiff behaviour. Softening formulas are given for rectangular and nonrectangular elements. Numerical tests of the improved element show excellent accuracy. The element accounts for transverse shear deformation, and works better than most other 12 degree of freedom elements that are restricted to thin plates
z:row.User2: plate bending element; finite element; softening; transverse shear deformation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Artificial adjustment of element stiffness with a particular reference to plate bending
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A finite element may satisfy all convergence requirements and work well except for being too stiff or too flexible when the mesh is coarse. The author discusses a technique for softening or stiffening such elements, provided that they have internal degrees-of-freedom. The technique is applied to a previously derived plate element, and the element is found to be much improved
z:row.User2: element stiffness; plate bending; finite element; convergence requirements; softening; stiffening

z:row.TitlePrimary: Finite element buckling analysis of homogeneous and sandwich plates
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Finite element buckling analyses of plates are performed by means of quadrilateral elements having 12 degrees-of-freedom. It is found that if the plate is capable of appreciable transverse shear deformation, initial-stress stiffness matrices that represent the lateral displacement by cubic polynomials do not yield convergence to correct results. An initial-stress stiffness that works satisfactorily for both homogeneous and sandwich plates is formulated. A Fortran listing of the associated subroutine is provided
z:row.User2: finite element buckling analysis; sandwich plates; quadrilateral elements; transverse shear deformation; stress stiffness matrices; convergence; subroutine; FORTRAN

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observations regarding assumed-stress hybrid plate elements
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Edge displacement of assumed-stress hybrid plate elements are commonly chosen as either linear, quadratic or cubic functions of the edge co-ordinate. The present paper examines the effect of this choice on the acceptability, accuracy, and possible zero energy modes of elements based on a linear stress field. It is concluded that triangular elements may be preferable to quadrilaterals, and that linear edge displacements are not desirable
z:row.User2: zero energy modes; linear stress field; assumed stress hybrid plate elements; finite element analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comment on `discrete element idealization of an incompressible liquid for vibration analysis' and `Discrete element structural theory of fluids'
z:row.Keyword: classical theories of fluid structure|finite element analysis|hydrodynamics|hydrostatics|surface tension
z:row.PeriodicalFull: AIAA Journal
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two papers (see ibid., vol. 8, no. 6, 1001, 1970 and vol. 9, no. 3, 457, 1971) discuss a `structural theory' of fluids. A finite element solution which resembles that used in solid mechanics is developed, using physical reasoning and intuition to account for the effects of sloshing surface tension, etc. This formulation is placed on a theoretical foundation, thus providing further insight and opening the way toward use of a variety of finite element models
z:row.User2: incompressible liquid; vibration analysis; sloshing; surface tension; finite element models

z:row.TitlePrimary: More reduced integration and isoparametric elements
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In a previous paper (see ibid., vol. 4, 449-50, 1972) the author commented on zero energy modes which may appear in isoparametric elements when reduced integration is used. Particular reference was made to plate elements having eight side nodes. It was suggested that if three internal d.o.f. (degrees of freedom) are used with a uniform 2 by 2 Gauss rule, accuracy may often be improved, but in some cases there may be complete failure owing to singularity of the assembled stiffness matrix. The present note advocates the use of a single internal d.o.f. in the eight-node plate element. Also, a scheme for avoiding the possible zero energy mode is suggested. As compared with selective integration this scheme is quite simple and does not reduce accuracy when non-rectangular elements are used
z:row.User2: zero energy modes; reduced integration; isoparametric elements; plate elements; eight side nodes; degrees of freedom; 2 by 2 Gauss rule; singularity; stiffness matrix; selective integration

z:row.TitlePrimary: Two hybrid elements for analysis of thick, thin and sandwich plates
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two general quadrilateral elements for plate bending are developed. Each has 12 degrees of freedom and accounts for transverse shear deformation effects. Each is built from four triangular elements whose properties are derived by the assumed-stress hybrid approach. Matrices needed to generate the stiffness properties of the triangular elements are explicity stated so as to facilitate their use. Numerical test cases, in which shear deformation effects range from negligible to very important, are used to illustrate the behaviour of the elements. It is concluded that the simpler of the two quadrilaterals is one of the best plate elements currently available
z:row.User2: hybrid elements; general quadrilateral elements; plate bending; degrees of freedom; transverse shear deformation effects; triangular elements; stiffness
